subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Unicode Status
msgSnippet: ... True. So in some contexts you may have to make do with reading Shavian letters. But you d not be able to type either Quikscript or Shavian on an internet
messageBody:
On 16 Apr 2013, at 15:48, Jean-François Colson <jf@...> wrote:

>> It's the one that's going to get results. Don't worry. You will be able to use the fonts you prefer, and you won't have to worry about how things are encoded.
>
> No. In an internet café, I won’t be able to install a Quikscript font if only a Shavian font is available on the computer.

True. So in some contexts you may have to make do with reading Shavian letters. But you'd not be able to type either Quikscript or Shavian on an internet cafe because you wouldn't be able to install a keyboard.

> In a plain text document, I won’t be able to mix Shavian and Quikscript text.

You will, orthographically. But I can't say that I believe that there is any chance whatsoever that the UCS will have both Shavian and Quikscript as two separate scripts.

> To mix Shavian and Quikscript text in the same document, I’ll need to endlessly change the font every time I change the script, while I may mix a Latin z, a Greek ζ and a cyrillic з using a single font and one of my multiscript home-made keyboard layouts if I wish.

Yes, that's right. But Quikscript isn't a separate script. It's a cursive variety of Shavian with some extensions. I'm sorry if this strikes you as unfortunate, but in the first place *I'm* not convinced, and even if I were, I can't think of any way that I could make a credible case to the UTC and WG2 about it.

Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com/
